# Goals of ventilation in ARDS

How to achieve better oxygenation?
*   Prevent over distension of baby lung (functional part of lung (a)) (by low tidal volume)
*   Recruit collapsed alveolar units (by optimal PEEP)
*   Prevent inhomogeneity in ventilation between dependent and non dependent regions. (**Prone positioning**)
*   To prevent VILI (By reducing stress and strain)

---

# Newer treatments in ARDS

*   Prone ventilation
*   EIT → Electrical impedance tomography
*   Inhaled drugs
*   HFOV
*   Inverse ratio ventilation
*   ECCO2R

# Prone positioning

*   Trans pulmonary pressure (Ptp) is defined as the difference between the airway pressure (Paw) and pleural pressure (Ppl)
*   $$Ptp = Paw - Ppl$$
*   Ventral transpulmonary pressure exceeds the dorsal transpulmonary pressure and greater expansion of the ventral alveoli than the dorsal alveoli

Eur Respir J. 2008;20(4):1017.Intensive Care Med. 1986;12(3):137

# Prone positioning

*   Alters the mechanics and physiology of gas exchange
*   Improves mortality in selected population
*   Refractory hypoxemia that is unresponsive to ventilator optimization

**How does it alter mechanics of gas exchange?**

*   Reduces the difference between the dorsal and ventral pleural pressure
*   ~~Ventilation more homogeneous~~
*   Decreases alveolar overinflation and alveolar collapse.
*   Improves perfusion of previously dependent lung, reduces shunt
*   Minimize stress and strain on alveoli.

# Proposed mechanisms for prone response

| | Physiologic effect | Clinical result |
|---|---|---|
| **Improved configuration between lung and thorax** | | |
| Heart is dependent | More homogeneous Ppl gradient in ventrodorsal and cephalocaudal planes | Improved ventilation distribution |
| Smaller volume of dependent lung | | Increased FRC (↓ shunt) |
| **Abdomen is unsupported*** | | |
| Secretion mobilization | Improved bronchial drainage | Improved ventilation |
| Improved aerosol delivery | Improved effect of aerosolized meds | Improved ventilation |
| More homogeneous perfusion | Less dependent perfusion | Improved V/Q matching (↓ shunt) |

proning
**Contraindications**
*   Acute bleeding (eg, hemorrhagic shock, massive hemoptysis)
*   Multiple fractures or trauma (eg, unstable fractures of femur, pelvis, face)
*   Spinal instability
*   Raised intracranial pressure >30 mmHg or cerebral perfusion pressure <60 mmHg
*   Tracheal surgery or sternotomy within two weeks

**Relative contraindications**
*   Shock (eg, persistent mean arterial pressure <65 mmHg)
*   Anterior chest tube(s) with air leaks\*
*   Major abdominal surgery
*   Recent pacemaker\*
*   Clinical conditions limiting life expectancy\* (eg, oxygen or ventilator-dependent respiratory failure)
*   Severe burns\*
*   Recent lung transplant recipient\*

---

<!-- Page 12 -->



# Complications
*   Nerve compression (eg, brachial plexus injury)
*   Crush injury
*   Venous stasis (eg, facial edema)
*   Dislodging endotracheal tube
*   Diaphragm limitation
*   Pressure sores (eg, facial)
*   Dislodging vascular catheters or drainage tubes
*   Retinal damage
*   Transient reduction in arterial oxygen saturation (differentiating) (dlt derecruitment (temporary) of Alveoli dlt proning (initially))
*   Vomiting
*   Transient arrhythmias

# Prone positioning

<mark>PROSEVA</mark>
✓ Does the early application of prone positioning improve mortality in severe ARDS?
*   RCT
*   01.01.2008. – 25.07.2011- France and Spain
*   Adult patients with severe ARDS who were intubated/ventilated for <36 hours at inclusion PaO2:FiO2 <150mmHg (20KPa) with FiO2 ≥0.6, PEEP ≥5, TV~6ml/kg, confirmed after 12-24 hours of ventilation
*   Excluded if contraindication to proning
*   474 patients randomized from 3449 patients with ARDS Intervention-Prone for at least 16 consecutive hours, for 28 days, or until improvement to set standard Control-Supine (semi-recumbent position)
*   Primary outcome: all cause mortality at 28-days 16% in prone vs. 32.8% in supine (P<0.001) adjusted odds ratio 0.42 (0.26-0.66) No increase in adverse events in prone group
*   <mark>Conclusion- Patients with severe ARDS have improved mortality with early and long proning session</mark>

# EIT

Image of a patient in a hospital bed with medical devices attached to their chest and abdomen.

*   Bedside tool- non radiological imaging of lung based on resistivity properties
*   To assess regional distribution of the ventilation in lungs-facilitates better optimization of PEEP
*   EIT guided peep titration the oxygenation is better, driving pressures are lower however does not have mortality benefit → Plat - Total PEEP
*   Requires increments or decrements to PEEP for optimal oxygenation

Zhao et al. Ann. Intensive Care (2019) 9:7
Somhorst et al. Critical Care (2022) 26:272

---

<!-- Page 15 -->

*   ✓ Sedated and paralyzed
*   ◎ PEEP titration started from 5-8 cm H2O at steps of 2cm H2O increments for 2 min until plateau pressure <35 cm H2O or unstable blood pressure
*   ✓ Then decreased in decrements of 2 cm H2O
*   ◎ The best point of intercept between collapse and overdistension percentage reflects the optimal PEEP

---

*Handwritten Notes:*

When you are titrating PEEP, when you are starting at a lower level & going to a higher level, if some amount of lung is recruited automatically Pplat will fall.
↓
This shows that the PEEP titration you are doing is fruitfull & much of lung is recruitable.

→ On the contrary: If you keep on increasing PEEP and your Pplat is also increasing → that means your PEEP is not able to recruit any part of the lung.

HFOV : High frequency oscillatory ventilation

*   **High RR** with very low **Vt(1-3ml/kg)**
    *   *Handwritten note*: 3 breaths/second = RR = 180/min
*   HFOV delivers breaths at **very high frequencies (typically 3-15 Hz)** and **low tidal volumes**, resulting in **minimal airway pressure fluctuations**.
    *   *Handwritten note*: 3 breaths - 15 breaths/sec
*   ✓ **Constant airway pressure promotes alveolar recruitment and improves V-Q matching and prevents atelectrauma**
*   **Decreases both barotrauma and volutrauma**
*   *Handwritten note*: Trials
    *   **OSCILLATE- Patients treated with HFOV had a significantly higher mortality and therefore it should not be used as standard treatment**
    *   **OSCAR- HFOV improved oxygenation but did not improve 30 day mortality**

# APRV: AIRWAY PRESSURE RELEASE VENTILATION

*   CPAP with intermittent pressure release phase.
*   Maintains adequate lung volume and recruitment.
*   Time cycled release phase to a lower set pressure.
*   In APRV, patients are predominantly ventilated at a high continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP), referred to as the "**Phigh**," which recruits alveoli and prevents their collapse. This facilitates oxygen diffusion and reduces atelectasis.
*   The "**Plow**" phase, typically brief, allows for passive exhalation and CO2 removal.

**FIGURE 3** | Airway Pressure Release Ventilation (APRV) is a pressure-limited, time-cycled mode. The Time Controlled Adaptive Ventilation (TCAV™) method of setting the APRV mode includes the following settings: 1) upper airway pressure ($P_{High}$); 2) lower airway pressure ($P_{Low}$); 3) time spent at $P_{High}$ ($T_{High}$); and 4) time spent at $P_{Low}$ ($T_{Low}$). Combined, $P_{High}$ and $T_{High}$ form the continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) Phase and impact end-inspiratory lung volume. The CPAP Phase releases to the combined $P_{Low}$ and $T_{Low}$, which form the Release Phase and impact end-expiratory lung volume. During the TCAV™ method of APRV, the ventilator cycles between the CPAP and Release Phases. During the release phase, the $T_{Low}$ set to terminate at 75% of the peak expiratory flow rate halts alveolar instability. Subsequently, the CPAP Phase maintains alveolar stability and recruits lung volume over time (hours to days).

## IRV :- Inverse Ratio Ventilation

_→ Normally in COPD/Asthma pts, most of times during ventilation alone, we are asked to prolong Expiratory time to prevent AutoPEEP._

*   **Mean airway pressure** is closely related to oxygenation, **a ventilation mode that can raise the mean airway pressure without increasing the Pplat could be a useful means of maintaining oxygenation.**
    _→ less dependent on total Insp. time → More Insp. time → More Mean airway pressure → More oxygenation_
*   The inspiratory time exceeds the expiratory time during IRV (the inspiratory to expiratory [I:E] ratio is inversed), increasing the mean airway pressure and **potentially improving oxygenation.**
    _useful in ARDS, (CO2) is not the main problem, its oxygenation, so Insp. time ↑ helps to improve oxygenation_
*   **The inspiratory time to expiratory time ratio was fixed at 2:1, and the tidal volume was initially set at 4–7 ml/kg predicted body weight.**

**High risk of hemodynamic instability due to auto peep.**
_High PEEP → ↓ Diastolic filling time → ↓ EF → shock_

# Inhaled vasodilators

*   Important physiologic benefits (eg, improved hypoxemia, lower pulmonary arterial pressure, and improved right-ventricular function and cardiac output) without systemic hemodynamic effects.
*   Inhaled prostacyclins are as effective physiologically as Inhaled NO and cost less.
*   Short term physiological benefits
*   Mortality benefit- yet to be proven, no role for routine use.
*   Rescue therapy for severe refractory hypoxemia in ARDS- Reasonable but controversial.

Respir Care2014;Feb;55(2):144-5

ECCO2R
*Extra corporeal CO2 Removal*

*   ARDSNet group demonstrated that the ventilation of ARDS patients with a low tidal volume (VT) of 6 mL/kg (vs. 12 mL/kg) significantly reduced mortality
*   However, recent results have shown that pulmonary hyperinflation still occurs in approximately 30% of ARDS patients despite this so-called “protective” ventilation
*   Studies suggest a beneficial effect of VT reduction, even in patients already at a plateau pressure (Pplat) < 30 cm H2O . The decrease in the VT and Pplat will also decrease the driving pressure, which has recently been identified as a major risk factor for mortality in ARDS patients
    *   {ULTRA LOW LPV}
*   A reduction in VT to less than 6 mL/kg to reach a low Pplat level may induce severe hypercapnia that may increase intracranial pressure, causes pulmonary hypertension, decreases myocardial contractility, reduce renal blood flow, and releases endogenous catecholamines
    *   {low TV ↓ low minute ventilation ↓ ↑ CO2 ↓ PH ↓}

---

<!-- Page 29 -->

Summary
ECCO2R

*   Acute hypercapnia can be a barrier to the use of guideline recommended lung-protective ventilation (LPV) and non-invasive ventilation (NIV) strategies.
*   Extracorporeal carbon dioxide removal (ECCO2R) therapy removes CO2 from a patient's blood with an extracorporeal circuit to effectively manage acute hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis that can result from lung-protective mechanical ventilation strategies.
    *Done when using ULTRA LOW LPV strategy*
*   ECCO2R therapy-enabled LPV and ULPV strategies may provide a cost-effective survival benefit in patients with moderate ARDS.

## Radiological phenotypes- personalized ventilation strategies?

*   **Non-Focal ARDS:** Diffuse alveolar opacities on CT; potentially more recruitable- benefit from higher PEEP
*   **Focal ARDS:** Localized loss of aeration, primarily in lower lobes- need lower PEEP to avoid overdistension



## RALE Score: Radiological Assessment of Lung Edema scores

*   Developed from plain chest radiographs to quantify pulmonary edema extent and density. Higher RALE scores correlate with lower PaO2/FiO2 ratios and worse survival outcomes.
*   Useful for prognostic enrichment in clinical trials targeting pulmonary edema resolution.

**<u>Physiological phenotypes</u> and personalized treatment?**
*   PaO2/FiO2 ratio
*   Ventilatory ratio (VR)
*   Driving pressure
*   Transpulmonary pressure.

These variables help assess oxygenation, ventilation, and lung mechanics to guide treatment strategies.
*   In pediatric ARDS, oxygenation is assessed using the <mark>oxygenation index (OI)</mark> or <mark>oxygen saturation index (OSI)</mark>.

# Protein Biomarkers in ARDS: Key Takeaways
Advances in protein biomarkers enhance understanding of ARDS pathophysiology, prognosis, and phenotype assignment, primarily studied in blood and bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF).



## Biomarkers:
*   Alveolar Type III Procollagen Peptide (PCP-III): Associated with fibroproliferation in ARDS, showing high sensitivity and specificity for diagnosis. *[handwritten: when found in BAL fluid]*
*   Routine Serum Biomarkers: In COVID-19, biomarkers such as ferritin, CRP, and d-dimer correlate with prognosis, but their role as actionable interventions remains unclear.



## Phenotyping Approaches:
Machine learning identify distinct ARDS phenotypes (hypo- and hyper-inflammatory) based on multiple biomarkers.
The hyper-inflammatory phenotype is linked to worse outcomes and has shown differential treatment responses in clinical trials.
The integration of protein biomarkers into clinical practice could enhance decision-making and improve patient outcomes in ARDS.
